I want to tell you a little bit about my background

came about. I actually started working at

up, and very interested in all that was going

145.62.text:
print shop and morning then in the pastry

151.31.text:
eventually ended up spending up most of my
time in the kitchen and cooking. Which was

156.37.text:
a great, wonderful, adventure. And after a
time I ended up then starting a family and

168.12.text:
wanted to change that and so I stopped cooking.
And about that time Alice started getting

174.63.text:
contracts to doing cookbooks and we worked

180.22.text:
of flipped over from cooking and went back

188.72.text:
working with Chez Panisse and still working
with Alice. The, it's all still about the

194.80.text:
same thing which is really about the beauty

202.37.text:
In printing and designing and in making images.
So this book, um, here's the dining room at

Chez Panisse about 5:30 before dinner begins.
It’s a little small place, its very intimate

and these menus that are collected here were

231.52.text:
For special occasions such as birthdays, I'm
going to come back to these images, but birthdays,

239.82.text:
anniversaries; there is an annual Bastille

250.18.text:
And the book is organized chronologically,
so the menus start actually in 1972 and alongside

258.09.text:
the menus are short text that tell sort of
different stories about maybe the events or

263.71.text:
the person it was made for or some visiting
luminary or some other occasion. And, uh,

279.52.text:
before we get into me really showing you those
menus I want to tell you a little bit about

283.71.text:
the process of how they are made. There are
letter press menus and I have a beautiful

290.67.text:
old cast iron letter press that is called
the Chandler and Price, C and P, and it is

298.58.text:
a, it has a clam shell action that sort of
opens and closes like this. And the paper

309.09.text:
is fed into the press by hand, it sits on
the area called the platen, it's a flat area

316.84.text:
of metal and that's the part that closes and
meets with the block or the type or whatever

322.85.text:
is being printed. You can see the block there
vertically. It's a one color press, prints

330.18.text:
one color of ink at a time. That's the ink
plate and the rollers are spreading the ink

338.79.text:
on the ink plate and the ink plate slowly
turns with each cycle of the press and will

345.08.text:
distribute that ink evenly. Then it comes
down and rolls over the surface of the block

349.79.text:
and the press closes and prints and paper
comes out and new paper comes in. And [clears

356.33.text:
throat] it was built, and this press is about
one hundred and twenty years old, still as

361.69.text:
solid as the day it was made. It was mainly
built to print type, metal type, hand-set

370.24.text:
and this is a sample of a little bit of type
setting. Um, and that's a process that is

378.53.text:
pretty much outdated now, purists still do
it but it's putting the type together letter

385.70.text:
by letter, space by space, space between the
lines, very, very laborious and handmade.

392.84.text:
But recently, the last twenty years or so,
the advent of polymer plate technology has

400.05.text:
really regenerated and revitalized letter
press printing. And that is still the same

406.38.text:
principle of relief printing, printing from
a raised service-like type. But this material

413.94.text:
is a thin layer of metal and on that is another
layer of polymer material that has a photo

421.33.text:
ground coating on the top, and to make the
plate digital type setting or some other form

430.42.text:
of image that can be output as a negative.
The negative and the polymer plate are sandwiched

438.35.text:
together, it's exposed to light and where
the light hits the photo ground on the polymer

444.17.text:
surface it hardens. And then the polymer plate
is washed in warm water, it's a great thing

450.59.text:
because there is no toxic photo chemicals,
it's a pretty benign process. And then the

456.91.text:
softer polymer material just rinses away and
you are left with that relief surface, so

462.53.text:
it's a very wonderful, easy technology that
means you don't have to set type and put the

470.08.text:
type all back in the box. So it then locks
up in the press, it sits on a magnetic base

480.12.text:
so that thin layer of metal on the back sits
on a magnetic base and then those two things

485.26.text:
together, the base and the plate equal a measurement
that is type high, which is the universal

492.42.text:
height of type, metal type. And so that means
anything you can make a plate out of you can

497.88.text:
lock that up in the press and print from it.
So a lot of small letter press shops have

502.02.text:
come up because you don't have to have all
the equipment and all the type and all of

507.41.text:
that, you just need a press and access to
a plate maker and it's done something pretty

512.78.text:
wonderful.
But how I make images primarily is linoleum

517.82.text:
block and similar to the polymer material,
linoleum block is a thin layer of linoleum

526.14.text:
mounted on wood and it's approximate type
high. I usually have to build up the back

531.65.text:
of it. And linoleum is a natural material,
this kind is called battleship linoleum. It's

538.07.text:
created out of powered cork and linseed oil,
it was developed by the military just before

543.33.text:
World War II to use as flooring for their
battleships and submarines. And which, you

549.90.text:
know, it's impervious to water and it's soft
enough to stand on so your legs don't get

555.28.text:
tired and it has a sort of a little porous
surface. It's not flat like metal or polymer

563.45.text:
and so when it's printed it has a sort of
stippled texture that I find really beautiful

569.76.text:
and you can really identify linoleum from
that look once you know what it is. And the

576.44.text:
process of making them, the prints, the blocks
themselves, is I start with a drawing and

584.41.text:
then, a pretty simple drawing like this as
you can see. And then you have to, I use drafting

590.75.text:
paper, turn it over and trace it on the back
because when you are working in printing you

597.00.text:
have to work in reverse. And then I put a
sort of graphite crayon on the back and taped

603.20.text:
that onto the block and then trace through
the drawing onto the block and that leaves

608.73.text:
something that looks like a pencil line on
the block. And I do that for, one block for

613.52.text:
each color in the print, cause press prints
one color at a time. And so if the image has

620.39.text:
four colors then there are four blocks and
then once that drawing has been transferred

627.59.text:
to the linoleum then it's cut and carved and
that's a process of removing all the negative

635.07.text:
space in the print. So as you can see with
this leaf the block on the bottom, you can

643.89.text:
see the lines of the gouges where the linoleum
has been removed so that only that part that

651.52.text:
I want to print is there. Here's an example
of this violet image, the image is made from

660.92.text:
four blocks and the first one on the left
is the dark green leaves of the image so that

670.02.text:
was printed first. And then the second block
is of the area under the leaves, just the

676.96.text:
solid, and that's a lighter green so that's
coming through the lines that are cut in the

682.80.text:
first image, the veins and inside the stalks
there. The third one is another line image

689.51.text:
of these, sort of outlines and interior lines
of the violets and then the last one is the

695.92.text:
tint, the purple tint color of the violets.
So those are printed one at a time. There

700.94.text:
is also a little bit of an orange that you
will see in the image that is the center of

704.73.text:
the flowers that I just added by water color,
it's a little hard to cut those tiny little

710.39.text:
spaces and get them in the right place. So
that's the basic process , here's the finished

716.86.text:
menu that that was made for, a New Years Eve
menu. So usually when I am making these menus

725.94.text:
that have text I will print the image first
and the last thing that happens is the type

730.99.text:
is added at the end, a separate run. So, as
I say, the organization of the book is the

menus are chronological and the first ones

745.85.text:
I didn't know how to do this linoleum work

752.26.text:
and metal type and using little type ornaments

that is sort of fun about this book is reading

kind of a snapshot of the history of Chez

served when and in this case for how much.
It's pretty astonishing, homemade pastries

for seventy five cents. Lindsay Shere , who

at the restaurant, made fantastic, fantastic

dollar which is pretty amazing. When the restaurant

and they just became famous, I don't know

money so [audience laughs] after about six

a single color and it's really pretty simple.

I can do this. And the other way that I was

printer. And so we would collaborate and I

when we were doing these, because it's a really

so it was usually a small number for maybe

king was for a friend of ours who had an absolute

quickly just this little menu in a couple

was for a dinner for James Beard who didn't

one spring and it was a time we were just

you see it in all the farmers markets but

green garlic so that's what decorated the

Years menus together for a few years in a

a mezzotint actually and this was an astronomical

moon within on calendar month. And it was

we couldn't resist that. But then I started

to get better at it doing, getting a little

here is another sample of the kind of menu

in, for just that small group of people, that

a special lunch for Richard Olney again, he

Femmes, which is just the ordinary wonderfully

he elevated that and really broke it down

but I drew it from life. Hadn't been doing

1181.14.text:
somehow get this color and so I drew the leaves

I had this kind of light bulb go off and thought

that turns around and spreads the ink, maybe

1200.62.text:
device that turned the ink plate and then

on the ink plate by hand and then just let

if you picture this menu turned on its side

see stripes of color; red, yellow, orange

through the press, all these different colors

1231.22.text:
work. And it's a little rough, you can see

1237.19.text:
not blending perfectly, but it was really

1244.53.text:
could really lead to something. I could play

1253.90.text:
better at this drawing thing and I have always

1260.50.text:
and with images and visually by older books.

1269.21.text:
herbals. This is an image from John Gerarde's

1278.31.text:
of a scientific text at the time of identifying

1284.03.text:
um, huge, big book. And these are wood cuts,

1290.28.text:
as linoleum only wood instead of linoleum.
So I used to pore over these and look at these

1297.05.text:
and think, try and figure out how to do it.
Maybe I could do something like that or I

1302.09.text:
would do very simplified versions of them.
And so I started trying to do that sort of

1309.50.text:
thing of this, like the garlic, bunch of garlic
here. Which again I was starting to draw from

1317.18.text:
life because that's what I wanted to see on

to sort of immolate or copy so I was just

1329.09.text:
And like this, you can see the direct influence

1339.07.text:
to add color to them so then I would do the
line work in black and then cut a block and

1344.82.text:
add the screen, to get a tint. The purple

1350.69.text:
put on with water color. The other source

1360.23.text:
Japanese woodblock prints and that whole tradition.

1370.77.text:
Song of the Garden that combined his images

1377.49.text:
book at the time It was printed in 1788. And

1387.71.text:
and beautiful where, and the combination of

1395.35.text:
And I was also looking at like these leaves
which had the line and the color and so graceful

1401.37.text:
and trying to think how can I sort of incorporate

1408.48.text:
that and here is an image made about that
time. This was actually a card that folded

1416.75.text:
in the middle, so it had a front and a back,

1423.98.text:
Japanese woodblock style. [pause] Here's another

1438.64.text:
the time because I was breaking these into
different colors and being able to put them

1442.90.text:
together and without necessarily the black
line, but composing an image of these separate

1450.84.text:
blocks just with color. And then using the

1458.87.text:
prints. And this is not anything literal about

1467.82.text:
it's about the season, about just a moment,
here's where we are right now. Another homage

1476.44.text:
to Japan with the fade at the top. One of

1484.87.text:
in the studio and satisfying is to keep pushing
the limits of the medium and keep pushing

1492.30.text:
the limits of the press itself. What can I
do of this particular machine with these particular

1498.91.text:
materials? And how one discovery leads to
another and the emphasis to try something

1505.93.text:
new. So I had been making some of these special

1516.23.text:
really wanted to have something every night
in there. Which was very difficult to accomplish,

1523.17.text:
especially with the changing menu every night,

hour really that that menu was getting determined.
So I worked out a system where using an 8-1/2

x 11 sheet I could print on one half of it

1546.87.text:
dinner on the computer, output that and then
put these in the copy machine and photocopy

1552.93.text:
that onto the interior and then fold it and
then there would be this combination of up

1558.76.text:
to date menu but something pretty and printed.

and printed them for about a year and a half

at a go. But which was just not sustainable

that could be printed offset and they could

for awhile. [pause]

they reproduce images from illustrations I

vegetable illustrations. So about the time,

on a book called Chez Panisse Vegetables where

I couldn't really spend too much time making

1663.24.text:
doing more and doing it more I did get better

fountain so-called technique of the multiple

leaves of this image. These are, these two

and trying not to be intimidated by the First

to impress upon the First Lady that the beautiful

projects. [ pause ] This is a New Year's Eve

[pause] Here again is that use of that multiple

block it's three blocks, so you can--,. It

put them right next to each other. And you

there is a little line, well that is the double

like a drawn line, it's just where they overprint
they make their own line and it helps to separate

1836.47.text:
one leaf from another, it's kind of a nice
way of subtly doing that. This was a dinner

1843.46.text:
for his Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales,
who visited the Bay Area and he's very involved

1854.69.text:
in Brittan in the organic food movement there,
and schools, and school gardens and organic

1863.52.text:
farming in general in England, it's pretty
great. So when he came to the United States

1868.62.text:
to visit he wanted to come to the Bay Area
because there is such a great movement here

1873.49.text:
and he wanted to visit the Edible School Yard
which they did. It's very exciting. And then

1880.48.text:
there was this big dinner for the both of
them. This is direct influence from Japanese

1889.20.text:
bird and flower prints. This was made for
the wedding of a very close friend, he and

1897.66.text:
his partner were married just before Proposition
8 passed on the ballet so they were legally

1904.77.text:
married in California. And the two birds on
the branch, they are red-winged black birds

1912.30.text:
and that, black birds the only the males have
the color on their wings, the females you

1920.27.text:
know are just all one color. So on this branch
are two male birds. And here's another wedding,

1933.83.text:
this one has quite a bit of detail with rosemary
flowers and this is a combination of printing

1941.37.text:
and then I went in and I filled in the color
and then the little tiny detail of those flowers

1947.06.text:
by hand. So this is really quite enjoyable
to do that kind of handwork actually and you

1953.77.text:
can do things that are otherwise too subtle
to do it on the press. Another wedding menu

1963.69.text:
that Chez Panisse did on a dinner on an island,
the wedding was on the beach. So I wanted

1973.67.text:
somehow to get sand on the menu itself and,
through some trial and error, I figured out

1982.76.text:
that if I put some vermiculite in a little
Cuisinart and then broke it up and then put

1989.71.text:
that on the wet ink when it came out of the
press it would stick to the ink and then actually

1995.13.text:
made something that looks very much like sand.
And that is the summary, so thank you I would

2007.57.text:
be happy to answer any questions if you have
any to talk about that.

2014.88.text:
[applause]
>> Male #1: What was the main influence of

2019.89.text:
your choice of that particular press and mechanism?
Was it it's availability or did you seek it

2026.01.text:
out?
>> Patricia: Well, um, that's actually the

2029.59.text:
press I first learned to print on when I was
in David Goines' shop. Someone he, he prints

2037.42.text:
on an offset press but someone had given him
this press and I was one of a couple of the

2046.21.text:
students of his and so an older friend of
his, a journeyman printer, came and taught

2053.33.text:
us how to operate this press and how to print.
And I just fell in love with it. And I've

2062.32.text:
operated a few other presses but I really
loved that one. I loved the size of it and

2068.82.text:
the simplicity of it. These presses are like
vintage cars where you could open the hood

2073.86.text:
and you could still how the whole thing works.
It's sort of the opposite of a computer but

2081.13.text:
it has, it has a very graceful, wonderful
mechanism that kind of fits the body. It's

2088.83.text:
not a huge big thing but it's good and solid
and very capable and, um, so I, when I decided

2098.88.text:
I wanted a press I started looking around
and I found one at a used equipment, printing

2104.88.text:
equipment place and there was that same press.
I thought, well that's for me.

2109.34.text:
>> Female #1: Have you ever had any typos?
>> Patricia: [giggles]I can't even count how

2118.39.text:
many typos. Yeah. [laughs] happens all the
time.

2121.90.text:
>> Female #1 : So when you do is it like "Oh
well" or do you have to redo everything?

2126.82.text:
>> Patricia: If you catch it in time, you
can change it. But after it's printed it's

2131.51.text:
"Oh well". But I always try and employ the
services of a friend who is a good proofreader.

2141.74.text:
You have to have somebody else look at it.
You just, because when you are setting, once

2147.09.text:
you start printing or once you set it, you
sort of stop seeing it as information, you

2152.34.text:
see it as shape and where it is on the page.
Proofreaders are a special group of people

2160.31.text:
to be able to catch that and I am really prone
to typos. Something I have to watch out for.

2166.99.text:
>> Female #2: Hi. For your menus that aren't
for special events, what is the lifetime of

2172.56.text:
the menu? How many times can you repeat them?
>> Patricia: I'm sorry I didn't hear the question

2174.98.text:
>> Female #2: What's the lifetime of a menu?
So how many times can you give it to like

2179.61.text:
a new customer before it gets bad or you know?
>> Patricia: You just use it once, they just

2185.28.text:
use them once.
>> Female #2: Oh, you just use them once?

2186.66.text:
Do they get to take it home?
>> Patricia: Yes, absolutely they get to take

2188.08.text:
them home.
>> Female #2: Oh great, ok.

2190.05.text:
>> Patricia: So that's what I mean. The restaurant
doesn't advertise, they have never advertised,

2194.69.text:
they have never done anything like that and
from very early on Alice knew about good printing,

2203.01.text:
knew about fine printing and she always loved
that. So that is something she wanted as part

2207.32.text:
of the restaurant. So like in the very early
days she would get local printers, and in

2215.30.text:
the Bay Area there has always been a real
printing community in the Bay Area. A lot

2218.77.text:
of letter press printers, there still are.
She would get these printers to make a special

2225.39.text:
menu or a week of menus or something like
that, very cleverly, in exchange for food

2231.03.text:
and wine. [audience laughs] So they were so
ready to do this and then there were always

2236.86.text:
these printers hanging around late night dinners,
a whole table of printers, drinking and drinking.

2243.03.text:
So it just became really a part of the signature,
the look and the style and the aesthetic of

2251.38.text:
the restaurant. But the ones that they use
now they have a, just kind of an inventory

2258.71.text:
of maybe twenty images on that 8-1/2 x 11
sheet. So then they can select for that night

2265.17.text:
what seems appropriate for that menu or this
season or that time of year. They print out

2273.21.text:
one for every dinner.
>> Female #2: Sorry, to follow up; what percentage

2276.83.text:
of people do you think bring home the menus
as opposed to leaving them there?

2280.72.text:
>> Patricia: Um, I would say on a nightly
basis maybe half. Of the special menus, you

2286.71.text:
know that hand printed menus, people catch
on to that and they take them home. One of

2291.42.text:
the things about letter press, if you are
familiar with it, is it has this very tactile

2300.07.text:
handmade quality. You may not know anything
about the process or you may not be familiar

2305.40.text:
with letter press really, but when you hold
it you know something has happened. This is,

2312.80.text:
it's handmade and you can tell and it communicates
something. And it's intimate, it's personal.

2320.25.text:
That's one of the things I love about the
medium is it's called letter press because

2327.15.text:
it punches the impression into the paper so
it has a kind of textural, sculptural aspect.

2334.60.text:
There are shadows where the letter forms are
and it's quite beautiful. I brought some for

2339.86.text:
you guys to see after its--. [pause]
>> Male #2 : So on the multi block projects,

2349.66.text:
how do you keep the registration correct?
>> Patricia: Yeah it is tricky. I work very,

2357.38.text:
very methodically. I mean printing is a methodical
process, it's not spontaneous. You have a

2363.50.text:
plan and you work step by step and so you
have methods of working. But I start with

2371.04.text:
that drawing you saw and when I put it on
the block and I trace over the drawing, that

2377.13.text:
part of the drawing for that part of the image,
I'm very faithful to that line. So then the

2386.98.text:
line is on the block and then when I am cutting
again I am very faithful to that line that

2392.18.text:
is the real line, not near it, not next to
it, it's the line. And then if you get everything

2398.97.text:
sort of on the blocks in the right place,
then you have the potential for registering

2404.68.text:
it on the press. Then it's a matter of printing
in a likewise methodical way, but it's just

2413.62.text:
being very careful at every stage. And you
know, my opinion, there are lots of ways to

2419.29.text:
go about this. Many kinds of printing it's
not such a tight registration, it's looser

2426.14.text:
and colors overlap and it's a little more
impressionistic looking. But my particular

2434.16.text:
style, my particular aesthetic is for really
close registration. I always kind of go back

2442.48.text:
to early botanicals and how beautiful they
are, those often were engraved or etched or

2452.93.text:
printed in one color and hand colored. A lot
of the really ones you might be familiar with.

2459.25.text:
But I am trying to do that on the press, I
am trying to kind of figure out a way. So

2462.45.text:
it's really just working very carefully.
>> Female #3: Do you have a favorite menu

2469.67.text:
or a favorite story from the menus in your
book?

2473.07.text:
>> Patricia: Um, it would be hard to pick,
it would be hard to pick one. The one I showed

2479.99.text:
you with the leaves where there light bulb
went off about the multi-colors, that one

2485.23.text:
is a favorite for me because it opened my
mind about what I could do on my press. And

2494.02.text:
I think there is a principle at work there
which is, that partly comes from learning

2503.15.text:
about cooking at Chez Panisse cause when the
restaurant first started, we really didn't

2509.47.text:
know what we were doing. There was a desire
to achieve something and cook fabulous food

2516.32.text:
but most of us were not trained. And so Alice
would make up these menus and put dishes on

2523.69.text:
the menus that we had never cooked before.
And there was one chef who came to work and

2529.50.text:
stayed for a long time, Jean Pierre Moulle,
he was classically trained and he was French

2535.19.text:
and he could like bring some hardcore information
and technique into the kitchen. But we would

2541.29.text:
just put things on the menu and then try it.
And one thing we figured out right away, and

2547.89.text:
you, because it's one menu, one night, you
are not duplicating the same thing over and

2553.41.text:
over again, you are always, there is always
the next night and new things. But if it didn't

2562.69.text:
work, if we were unsatisfied with that dish,
the thing is you were just like let's put

2567.08.text:
some version of that one the menu next week.
And we would do it again, and we would do

2571.74.text:
it again until we got it and then we had that
technique or we had that dish in the repertoire.

2580.52.text:
Same thing with something that worked fabulously
well, we would do it again soon so that we

2585.82.text:
wouldn't forget. Because when things are changing
so often it is hard to remember, you know

2596.23.text:
you're just moving all the time. So that same
way of, that same approach I took into the

2605.24.text:
print studio when I stopped working in the
kitchen, which is go for what you want to

2613.08.text:
see. I would try it and sometimes it would
work and sometimes it wasn't but then I would

2618.36.text:
try it again, try it again. And eventually
you would kind of get there, so for me some

2624.77.text:
of the memorable menus are the ones where
I really, I really discovered something.

2632.14.text:
>> Male #3: Thanks for coming, I love your
work. I have a mimeograph machine, I am terrible

2640.25.text:
at using it. But I have a series of realizations
like, oh it matters what ink you use, oh it

2646.37.text:
matters what paper you use, but I missed the
beginning of your talk. I was curious about

2650.35.text:
how far down the rabbit hole do you go with
the particular paper? I know people who, like,

2656.96.text:
they are not happy with what's available so
they try to make their own. I was just curious

2660.42.text:
like do you enjoy that part of it and how
far do you go to get it just to your specifications?

2664.75.text:
>> Patricia: That's a good question. Very,
very far down the rabbit hole. [audience laughs

2671.14.text:
lightly] Another tremendous pleasure in printing
and I thinks it's one of the things that really

2677.18.text:
hooks people, especially letter press printers,
is paper. A paper is just beautiful, beautiful

2683.34.text:
stuff, quality papers. And they all print
differently, they all feel different, they

2689.81.text:
have slightly different textures and colors.
So you have to make adjustments for all of

2693.45.text:
that and you know when I would be conceiving
of a menu, making a plan, part of that is

2701.97.text:
what paper, what color is the paper, what's
it's going to do in the press. And because

2711.08.text:
not all papers are suitable for block printing
or letter press printing, that kind of limits

2716.45.text:
certain things. But fortunately most fine
papers are really, really good. I don't make

2724.57.text:
paper, but you know we have done all kinds
of things like print an image and then make

2735.31.text:
a fan out of it. Cut it and glue it to sticks
in order to get a printed fan, and then you

2740.00.text:
just, there are all kinds of things possible.
You build up your knowledge of materials and

2749.28.text:
inks and mixing colors and what happens when
you put one color on top of another and what

2756.70.text:
are you likely to get and all of that. It's
a cycle, it's trial and error, basically no

2763.93.text:
rules, you just keep, you do it until you
get what you want. Yeah, yeah, but that's

2770.16.text:
the fun of it. That's what I was saying, that
discovery is, um, you start in one place and

2775.48.text:
you just keep adding to that and you get into
all kinds of new places. [pause] Anyone else?

2791.68.text:
Thank you, thank you very much.
